content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The United States has had persistent trade deficits since 1978, with significant deficits with countries like China, the European Union, Japan, and Mexico. In 2010, the trade deficit rose to $497.8 billion, with China alone accounting for 42% of the deficit. The United States has one of the most open economies but faces trade barriers with its partners, accounting for 42% of the trade deficit. SEC. 2. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. Establishment of the Emergency Trade Deficit Commission, composed of 11 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders to represent labor, small businesses, and manufacturing interests. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission is composed of 11 members appointed by various leaders from the Senate and House of Representatives to represent different interests. The Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives sets qualifications for members of the Emergency Trade Deficit Commission, limiting presidential appointments to one executive branch official and requiring expertise in specific fields for other appointments. Members must not be officers or employees of the United States. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission in the United States aims to appoint members representing diverse economic perspectives to address trade imbalances. Members will be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment for the Commission's lifetime. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission in the United States aims to appoint members representing diverse economic perspectives to address trade imbalances. Members will be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment for the Commission's lifetime. The Commission's vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission shall hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings will be called by the Chairperson. The members will elect a chairperson and vice chairperson, and a majority of members will constitute a quorum for decision-making with each member having one equal vote. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission in the United States will have diverse economic perspectives represented by appointed members. The Commission's duties will be outlined in Section 3 of the Act. The Commission is tasked with examining the causes of the US trade deficit and providing recommendations to reduce trade imbalances. This includes assessing macroeconomic factors like currency practices and foreign government purchases of US assets. The Commission is tasked with assessing trade deficits with countries, analyzing barriers to market access, investment requirements, technology transfer, adherence to labor standards, and their impact on competition and consumer choices. The Commission will analyze the impact of free trade agreements on the US trade deficit, as well as investment flows in and out of the country on the deficit. The Commission will analyze the impact of outbound investment and relocation of production facilities overseas on the US trade deficit, as well as the effects of foreign direct investment in the country on standards of living and production. The Commission will examine the impact of United States bilateral investment treaties on the trade deficit, imports of energy products, and how foreign policy influences economic and trade policies. They will also identify the consequences of the trade deficit on the domestic economy, manufacturing capacity, and job quality. The Commission will assess the impact of trade deficits on manufacturing capacity, job quality, wages, and economic growth. Recommendations will include strategies for improving trade balances and utilizing trade policy tools effectively. The Commission will examine enforcement mechanisms to address trade deficits, identify policies to enhance competitiveness of US manufacturers, improve coordination of Federal departments relating to trade, and enhance trade data collection and reporting. The Commission will submit a report to the President and relevant committees containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations within 16 months of the Act's enactment. Members can also include additional views in the report. The Commission is granted powers to fulfill its duties. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission's personnel matters are addressed in Section 6 of the Act. The Commission members are compensated based on their status as federal government employees or not. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided to members at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. They can also determine their compensation independently. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Commission to carry out the Act. The Comptroller General to audit the Commission's financial books within 6 months of termination. The Commission terminates 30 days after submitting its report. Moratorium on free trade agreements until the Commission's report is delivered to Congress and the President.
